I assessed the criticality mainly using the players' previous % scores; and their role in the task. If the player had to score 20 for the team to win; then they played an entirely crucial role in the task. If they shared the responsibility for achieving 20 clicks with another player; they played a 50% crucial role.I assigned full blame to players who were required to achieve the full 20 clicks; because even if the rest of the players had achieved it; the team would not have won due to that players' failure. I assigned partial blame to players who shared the responsibility with another; and no blame to those who achieved the 20 clicks.I assessed criticality in the 3rd stage in a similar way. Full criticality to players who HAD to achieve the 20 clicks; and partial to those sharing the burden.;;;;;;;;

1) You were more critical to the experiment if you were required to reach the criteria alone; and if you all had to achieve the criteria you were equally as critical. 1) I put full criticality for participants who's reaching the full criterion was essential and divided criticality between those who at least one needed to reach it.2) Similarly I put full blame for those who's completion was critical and divided blame between those who shared responsibility; putting 0 blame for anyone who did reach their criterion.3) I divided criticality equally between them as when one out of two needed to complete the criterion; each has 50% criticality.;;;;;;;;;;;;;

Assessed the criticality of the players by thinking that if they had to reach 20 clicks; they were more critical.  Also; if one of two players had to get 20 clicks; the one with a higher practice percentage was more critical.I assigned more blame when players had to reach 20 clicks than when it was at least one of twoIn the third stage; I assigned criticality equally; as it did not matter whether players played simultaneously or not.  They were as critical as eachother as one of them had to succeed and both had same practice percentages.;;;;;;;;;;

I assessed the criticality of players in the first part according to their peformance in the practice trials; the better they did the more probabilities they had to be critical for the team since they would be more likely to get a good result. I also assessed their criticality depending on their position in the team; for example; if two players where in the position where one of them should reach the challenge then the criticality was somewhat shared. If a player HAD to meet the challenge in order for his team to win then he was more critical to the team than the others. In the second stage of the experiment I assessed the blame depending on whether they managed to meet the challenge (if they have then I didn't blame them at all); and on their position in the team; for example; if there were two players where one of them had to reach the challenge and didn't then the blame is shared amongst the two who either of them had to reach the challenge. I put more blame on players who HAD to meet the challenge. Finally; I assessed the criticality in the third stage according to their performance in the practise trials. ;;;;;;;;;;;

1) How likely they were to meet the criterion and how much of a role they had in determining whether the team as a whole won the task.2) If they were paired with someone else in meeting the criterion ie. only one of them had to do it - then they had less blame than if it was essential for them to meet the criterion for the whole team to complete the task3) seemed pretty equal; because they both had equal chances of meeting the criterion and it was only essential for one of them to meet the criterion for them both to win. So if the participant knew that they had failed the criterion and the other person had to; they would still feel critical of the other person because they felt that the responsibility of the task was split between them.;;;;;;;;;;;;;

1) In the game where all players have to complete the challenge for the team to win; all members are as equally critical in the team. When one player have to complete the challenge and either one of the other two have to do the same; the importance of the other two are slightly lower than the one who have to complete the challenge. When only one of the player have to complete the challenge; the one who performs the best are slightly more critical for the success of the team than the other two.2) If it was critical for a player to complete the challenge for the team to win; they are to blame the most if they fail to accomplish the task. If it was critical for only either one of two participants to complete the task; the blame is divided between them. The one who performed worse had more blame.3) The one who is more likely to complete the task is more critical for the team. When both are required to complete the task; they are equally as critical.;;;;;;;;;

1) I used their role in the game to assess their criticality; as if they were responsible for twice as much of the game; then they are twice as critical.  Also; if responsibility was shared; then the person who was most likely to reach the quota was considered more critical.  2) I assigned blame using how much of the game they were responsible. If the responsibility was shared then the blame would be halved.  If in a shared situation; one failed to reach the quota; then they would still be blameless; as the other person would have succeeded for them.  3) I assessed the criticality on the 3rd stage using probablities;  but I thought they should still be similarly critical; regardless of timing.  ;;;;;;

1) according to the importance of their performance considering the game rules (i.e. when one out of two needed to reach the criterion; criticality of both should add up to criticality of one player having to reach the criterion)2) relative to the criticality3) again according to the importance of thei performance;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

The criticality of the players is linked to the role they have been assigned. If they are assigned into team work; their criticality would be shared among the team and vice versa. If players who are less able to manage the game are assigned to the individual task; they would have higher criticality to win the game and vice versa.Players who are more able to manage the game would be blamed more likely than the ones who are not well managed the game if they fail to reach their requirements. Both players are equally critical in the 3rd stage. ;;;;;;;;;;;;;

If the condition was that all had to meet the criterion; all players are critical. If the condition was that one out of all had to meet the criterion; the criticality depends on how good the player had been at meeting the criterion (i.e. the better the player; the more critical). If the condition was that the first and either one out of the second or third player had to meet the criterion; the first player is very critical; whilst the criticality of the second and third depended on their presupposed ability.Blame would be dependent on whether one achieved the criterion; regardless of their presupposed ability.When the players did the task one after the other; the second player would be more critical; since that player would directly affect the outcome in the case where the first player did not meet the criterion. In other words; the first player could have or not have met the criterion; whereas he second player MUST meet the criterion in the case where the first player did not. If both players played simultaneously; both of them are equally critical.;;;;

My assessment of effort was based on the players past scores in comparison to other players scores if more than one person's winning would allow the team to win; if the player was individualised and therefore had to win themselves; it was based on their past scores being high or low would cause a lower or higher effort score respectively. The blame was accounted for by the requirement to get over 20 clicks by the individual; I did not use past scores as a reference for this. The effort in the 3rd stage was based on a comparison with the partners past score and whoever had the highest score was most likely; in my mind; to give the greatest effort. In instances where one individual took part after their partner; a higher level of effort was chosen as if the partner had previously failed it would cause greater expectance and therefore effort on the part of the participant. 1. The players that had very low score would try extra hard; unlike the ones with high score that would feel extra confident. If one of two players had to get the score then they would feel more assured that the other players would get it. However; if one of the two had a very low score he/she might feel challenged and would try extra hard. If a player was trying alone to get a score he/she would try harder.2. Those who had to get the score by themselves were not as much to blame because they would put more effort. The others would put more trust in their teammate getting it if they didn't.3. Not very much because they will feel assured that the others would get it. However; they might feel a little bit challenged and try a little.;;;;;;;;;;;;

1) if they did badly; they will probably put in more effort as they are aware that the other members can see their result and want to save face. In the challenge where they all had to meet the criterion they will probably all put in a lot of effort except if one player did really badly in which case the other =s will think there is no point. In the challenge where at least one had to meet the criterion the one who scored the most probably pput in the most effort and the others left it to him/her. in the challenge where one specific member had to reach the criterion; that member probably put in the most effort.2) those who met the criterion desreved the least blame and those who didnt; equal amounts.3) equal amounts of effort but not full because they can rely on the other.I;;;;;;;;;;;;

1. depending on who else needs to complete the challenge in order to win; so ifthe full responsibility is on the individual to win; they will put in more effort; if they are working in a pair; they will expect the other one to put in the effort and therefore will not put as much effort in. 2. if the players were working in a pair; they were less likely to blame because it was a group effort; but if they were working individually; they were fully to blame if they did not complete the task. 3. It depends on if they are doing the challenge at the same time; if they are they will put in the same ammount of effort but if one goes after the other; they will put in more effort. ;;;;;;

I used the structure of each challenge to help me decide how much effort the players will exert. For instance; if it is required that player 1 needs to fulfilm the critereon; but only one of player 2 or 3 have to; then I would assume that player 1 would exert more effort than players 2 or 3 simply because player 1 has more sole responsibility and would therefore feel more pressure to achieve. Similarly; I used the challenge structure to assess blame. I assumed that if player one is required to fulfil the critereon then he/she would exert more effort; therefore I assumed that they would be less to blame since they must have done their best. Therefore; If players 2 and 3 failed to reach the criterion then I assumed this was because they did not exert enough effort in the task and so I said they were the most to blame. In the third stage i assumed that both players exerted the same amount of effort because they had equal pressure to acheive; although it is likely that in real life one of the players would be likely to rely on the other to achieve and not put as much effort in themselves. However this would require more information on the personalities of the participants.;;;;;;;;

1) If the player knew that he had to meet the criterion in order for the team to win; he would put in more effort than if only either he or another player had to meet the criterion. This is because the success of the team depends more on him. If the player performed better at the practice trials; he would put in more effort if there was only one player required to meet the criterion for the team to win. The player put in more effort because he did better than the rest and the success of the team probably depends on him. If all players are required to meet the criterion; the one with the lowest performance on the test trials would put in more effort because he knew that it is likely that he would not meet the criterion and cause the whole team to lose.2) If the player had to meet the criterion for the team to win; he is more to blame if he fails than if only he or another player had to meet the criterion. 3) If both players played simultaneously; both would put in the same effort because they would not know how the other performed. If one player played first; he would put in less effort than the other because he knew that if he didn't perform well the other player can still help the team win. How much effect the second player put in depends on the performance of the first player. If the first player met the criterion he would not put in much effort. If not; he would put in more effort.;;;;;;;;

I based my effort score; firstly on whether they were working with someone in a team; so if only one out of three needs to pass; less effort will be shown; as opposed to one person having to pass. I also based it upon their accuracy in practice trials. So if a person was by themself in a team; so had to make the criteria; but had a lower accuracy in the trials; they would make more effort. If however they were in a team; the person with the lowest accuracy may make less effort as they will depend on someone with a higher accuracy. I assessed the blame by who had failed to meet the criteria. And that if all failed; they all had equal amounts of blame; afterall this is a team game; and not one person can take the fall. More effort would be demonstrated in the third part; as there is one person depending on you and the likelihood of passing is lower; and so you need to work harder to pass. There were too many teams to assess; i think 20 would have been fine. ;

1) In a group (when either one has to complete the task within 2 or 3 people); people don't put alot of effort as they assume that much work will be done by the others. However; if they are all individuals; they compete with each other. What's more; in the 2-1 condition (2 people in a group vs. 1 person); the person who isn't within a group will compete more than before; as he.she want to beat the group.2) Although it is understandable that some do not put that much effort when in a group; one should be blamed if he/she was alone because the only explanation of such result would be 'laziness'.3) competition;;;;;;;;

1) more effort if they definitely had to get 20 clicks as the whole team was depending on them = pressure. whereas if only one out of two people; or one out of 3 people; had to get 20 clicks; then the pressure was less and they could share the blame and wouldn't be blamed by the whole team if they failed. they would also put in less effort because they would hope that the other people would do well; so they didn't have to. also if only one person needs to get 20 clicks; and they saw that people did better than them on the practice stage; then they may try less hard. if someone did well on the practice stage; and saw others did badly; they may try harder to ensure the team passed.2) more blame if a person who definitely needed to get 20 clicks; failed to do so; as they knew that they needed the 20 clicks so should have tried harder. less blame if only one of two people needed to get 20 clicks; as it wasn't definite that they needed to get the 20 clicks. however they should still try hard; which is why even if the team fail and 1/2 people did get 20 clicks; the person who didn't should still be blamed; even though technically it wouldn't have made a difference.3) more effort for the person who did it afterwards as they have the pressure of not knowing how well the person did before; and wanting to do better than them.

1) If the player had a higher percentage of reaching the criterion; the more effort they would exert on the challenge where at least one needs to reach the criteron. For the other experiments the lower the percentage of reaching the criterion where they must put an extra effort for the team to win the challenge; those will need to put more effort into it; otherwise the whole team fails. 2) The people who had to reach the criterion are blamed less than the ones where they just had to have one that reached the criterion between the two.3)In the third stage; both will put relatively the same effort in order for them to win the challenge.;;;;;;;;;;;

The amount of effort each player exert depends on the capability of oneself relative to the team members. If they are less capable than their team members and the challenge only requires one member to reach the criterion; they will put in less effort. For case where all members' performance are taken into account; the less capable member will exert more effort than others; since they know that they might be a burden to the team. The assignment of blame depends on how crucial one is in determining if the team wins the challenge or not. The greater the contribution of one's performance to the team's performance; the more blame is assigned to the member. In the third stage; the amount of effort put in by both players will be equivalent regardless of whether they did the challenge simultaneously or one after another. ;;;;;;;;;;

1) If the challenge required all four people to win; then I assumed each person would exert the same amount of effort to help their team win. But I also took their average scores into account; so if someone was really good at the game then they might not have tried as hard as someone who was worse and so knew they might not win. If only one person had to win; then I assumed that the person who was the best at the game would exert the most effort and try and win for their team; whilst the others would not try as hard because they know that there is a better person than them in the team who will win for them. If there were two stages to the challege; then I assumed that the first player would exert the most effort in order to pass the first stage and not let their team members down; because they would feel guilty that they didn't give the others a chance to win the challenge.2) If the players who were required to pass in order for the team to win did not; then I assigned the blame mostly to them because they didn't even give the other team members a chance to try and win. 3) As there are only two people in this challange I thought that they would exert the same amount of effort because they feel equally to blame if their team loses. Also; they may feel competitive even though it's a team game; because there are only two of them; and so they would try harder to win because of this.;;;;;
